title: Vehicle Handling: Stay Smooth and in Control
summary: Build the steering, braking, and gear skills that keep your car stable in bends, junctions, and challenging conditions.

sections.title: Why Vehicle Handling Matters
sections.body: Smooth control keeps passengers comfortable, tyres gripping, and fuel consumption low. It’s also essential for avoiding skids and maintaining confidence.

sections.title: DVSA Essentials
items: Use progressive braking: press gently at first, increase pressure, then ease off as you stop.
Look and steer where you want to go—your hands follow your eyes.
Match gear to speed; block change when appropriate to keep the car stable.

sections.title: Core Handling Skills
items: Steering: use the push-pull method or controlled hand-over-hand at low speed for precision.
Braking: plan early, brake in a straight line before corners, and cover the brake when needed.
Acceleration: apply smoothly to maintain traction, especially when exiting bends.

sections.title: Bends and Hills
sections.body: Approach bends at a speed that lets you stop within the distance you can see. On hills, select a lower gear early and use handbrake control to prevent rolling back.

sections.title: Low-Grip Conditions
items: Wet or icy roads: increase following distance, use higher gears to reduce wheelspin, and avoid harsh inputs.
Loose surfaces: steer gently and allow longer braking distances.
ABS and traction control: understand how they feel so you remain calm if they activate.

checklist.label: I brake progressively and finish braking before steering into a bend.
I select gears that match speed and road conditions, using block changes when suitable.
I steer smoothly using push-pull or controlled hand-over-hand when manoeuvring.
I can move off uphill and downhill without rolling or stalling.

practiceTips.label: Narrate your control
practiceTips.detail: During lessons, say ‘mirrors, ease off, brake, gear, position’ as you approach hazards. The script keeps actions smooth.

practiceTips.label: Theo’s cup test
practiceTips.detail: Place a half-full reusable cup in the cup holder (with a lid). Aim to keep the liquid steady—smooth control saves fuel and keeps the car balanced.

practiceTips.label: Skid awareness
practiceTips.detail: Watch DVSA videos on ABS and traction control. Knowing what to expect reduces panic if systems activate.

questions.prompt: How should you brake when approaching a bend?

options.label: Brake hard halfway through the bend
options.explanation: Braking in the bend can unsettle the vehicle and lead to loss of control.

options.label: Brake progressively before the bend, then ease off as you steer
options.explanation: Finishing braking before steering keeps grip balanced and the car stable.

options.label: Don’t brake at all
options.explanation: You may need to reduce speed—plan early rather than relying on luck.

options.label: Brake sharply just before you exit the bend
options.explanation: Late, sharp braking destabilises the car and can cause understeer.

questions.prompt: When might you use a block gear change?

options.label: When you want to skip unnecessary gears while slowing down
options.explanation: Block changing keeps the car stable and reduces workload when the road is clear.

options.label: Only when accelerating hard
options.explanation: Block changes are typically used during deceleration.

options.label: Never—it’s not allowed on test
options.explanation: DVSA examiners expect smart gear choices, including block changes when appropriate.

options.label: Only when driving an automatic car
options.explanation: Block gear changes apply to manual transmissions—automatics handle ratios themselves.

questions.prompt: What’s the safest way to move off uphill?

options.label: Release the handbrake and then find the bite point
options.explanation: This risks rolling back and failing the manoeuvre.

options.label: Find the bite point, check mirrors, then release the handbrake while adding gas
options.explanation: Balancing the pedals before releasing the brake prevents rolling back.

options.label: Hold the car with the clutch only
options.explanation: Riding the clutch overheats it and gives less control.

options.label: Release the handbrake and rely on the parking brake to catch you
options.explanation: The parking brake is the handbrake—once released, there’s nothing left to hold the car.

questions.prompt: What should you do if ABS activates under heavy braking?

options.label: Release the pedal immediately
options.explanation: ABS pulses to help you steer—lifting off removes the assistance.

options.label: Keep firm pressure on the brake and steer around the hazard
options.explanation: ABS allows you to brake and steer; keep your foot down and steer smoothly.

options.label: Pump the brakes rapidly
options.explanation: Pumping is for cars without ABS—modern systems already pulse the brakes for you.

options.label: Change down a gear immediately
options.explanation: Focus on braking and steering; changing gear mid-emergency wastes valuable time.

questions.prompt: You’re descending a long, steep hill. How should you control your speed?

options.label: Select a lower gear and use the brakes gently
options.explanation: Engine braking plus light brake pressure prevents overheating and keeps speed in check.

options.label: Coast in neutral to save fuel
options.explanation: Coasting removes engine braking and reduces control—stay in gear.

options.label: Hold the clutch down and rely on the brakes alone
options.explanation: Keeping the clutch down removes engine braking and risks brake fade.

options.label: Accelerate intermittently to keep momentum
options.explanation: Speeding up on a descent is unsafe and increases stopping distance.
